Situation1: All household chores must be coordinated because relatives are visiting, and the home needs to be fully presentable.
Expectation2: Repair or replace damaged wooden structures or components
Situation2: A house has structural wood damage from termites, and the carpenter needs to provide an urgent repair plan
Story:
I stood in the kitchen, scrubbing the counters for the third time, my phone buzzing insistently in my pocket. My spouse was in the next room, vacuuming, both of us tense as we tried to make the house spotless before the relatives arrived. Every surface had to shine, every room had to be perfect—my partner’s voice echoed in my head, “We need to make a good impression.” I knew how important this was, how much it meant to share the load and show we were a team.

But my phone wouldn’t stop. It was the owner of the old house I’d inspected yesterday, her voice urgent in the voicemail: “The termites have eaten through the beams. I need your repair plan today, or the whole place could be unsafe.” As a carpenter, I couldn’t ignore it—someone’s home, maybe their safety, depended on me. My mind raced, torn between the expectation to be present and helpful at home, and the professional duty to respond immediately to a crisis. I stared at the mop in my hand, heart pounding, feeling the weight of both worlds pressing in, unsure which one I could let down.
